title: 112_hr3159
content: The Act is titled the "Foreign Aid Transparency and Accountability Act of 2012" and provides guidelines for United States foreign development assistance. The "Foreign Aid Transparency and Accountability Act of 2012" aims to evaluate the performance of US foreign development assistance, establish guidelines for measurable goals and monitoring, and coordinate monitoring processes across federal departments and agencies. The guidelines established under the "Foreign Aid Transparency and Accountability Act of 2012" aim to provide direction to federal departments and agencies on monitoring and evaluating US foreign development assistance programs. They focus on activities related to resource monitoring, project evaluation, program impact assessment, and analysis for project and program design. Monitoring and evaluation of programs involve building measurable goals, performance metrics, and guidelines for development and implementation. It includes collecting and disseminating knowledge to aid professionals and partners. Monitoring and evaluation of programs involve setting measurable goals, performance metrics, and guidelines for development and implementation. This includes distributing evaluation reports internally, establishing annual monitoring and evaluation agendas, applying rigorous methodologies, and partnering with experts in the field. The curr_chunk discusses the development and implementation of guidelines for monitoring and evaluation programs in foreign development assistance. It also mentions the requirement for a detailed report to be submitted to Congress on measurable goals and performance metrics. The Comptroller General of the United States is required to submit a report to Congress analyzing the effectiveness of actions taken by federal departments and agencies in planning, conducting, and utilizing foreign development assistance program evaluations. The report must be submitted within one year of the enactment of the Act and may include a classified annex. The Comptroller General of the United States must submit a report to Congress within two years of the Act's enactment. The report will analyze the guidelines and implementation of foreign development assistance by major federal departments and agencies. Evaluation is defined as the systematic collection and analysis of information to improve program effectiveness and inform future decisions. The Act requires an internet website to provide comprehensive, timely, comparable, and accessible information on US foreign development assistance programs. The President shall direct the Secretary of State to establish a website for public access to information on US foreign development assistance. Each Federal department or agency administering such assistance must publish and update program details quarterly. Information will be provided on a program-by-program and country-by-country basis to ensure transparency. To ensure transparency and accountability of US foreign development assistance, information such as country assistance strategies, budget documents, obligations, expenditures, and evaluations must be published online within 90 days. If the inclusion of required information on the Internet website jeopardizes health, security, or national interests, the Federal department or agency must provide briefings to Congress or submit a written report instead. The Internet website must include information for specific fiscal years, with details for each year increasing over time. If sensitive information is excluded, it can be shared with Congress in classified form. The Internet website must include information for specific fiscal years, with details for each year increasing over time. For fiscal year 2017 and beyond, a searchable database link will be provided for information from fiscal years prior to 2010 but within the last 5 fiscal years. SEC. 4. If information required under section 3 is not provided for a foreign development assistance program, the head of the relevant Federal department or agency must brief congressional committees monthly on why the information is not on the Internet and when it will be. SEC. 5. Up to 5% of funds for foreign development assistance programs can be used to implement this Act. SEC. 6. Definitions. The term "appropriate congressional committees" refers to specific committees in the House of Representatives and the Senate. "United States foreign development assistance" includes aid for foreign development and economic support, authorized under the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961. The text chunk discusses various chapters and acts related to foreign development assistance, including the Overseas Private Investment Corporation, International Organizations and Programs, International Narcotics Control, Economic Support Fund, and the Millennium Challenge Act of 2003.
